intro: Staphidiastrum cognatum, commonly known as the Florida bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in wetlands and swampy areas, thriving in moist, acidic soils. It has lance-shaped leaves and produces showy, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Staphidiastrum cognatum is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ecological importance and adaptability to aquatic environments.
